snippet: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in an uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.
abstract: Nusra Front, lone Syrian rebel group with explicit approval from Al Qaeda, has become one of uprising's most effective fighting forces, posing challenge to United States and other countries that want to support rebels but not Islamic extremists; US hopes to isolate group to prevent it from inheriting Syria or fighting on after Pres Bashar al-Assad's fall to pursue its goal of Islamic state.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad, and Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon. Reporting was contributed by Hania Mourtada from Beirut; Duraid Adnan and Yasir Ghazi from Baghdad; employees of The New York Times from Mosul, Iraq, and the provinces of Anbar and Diyala; and Michael R. Gordon from Dublin.

lead_paragraph: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in an uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.

headline.seo: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
headline.main: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
headline.print_headline: Syria Rebels Tied To Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
